title: Two functions of y and polar area

content.question: The figure above shows the graphs of the line <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>5</mn> <mn>3</mn> </mfrac> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DE7@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and the curve C given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi>y</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EF1@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Let S be the shaded region bounded by the two graphs and the x-axis. The line and the curve intersect at point P. (a) Find the coordinates of point P and the value of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D37@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for curve C at point P.

frqParts.text: The figure above shows the graphs of the line <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>5</mn> <mn>3</mn> </mfrac> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3DE7@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and the curve C given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <msqrt> <mrow> <mn>1</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi>y</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </msqrt> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EF1@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Let S be the shaded region bounded by the two graphs and the x-axis. The line and the curve intersect at point P. (a) Find the coordinates of point P and the value of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D37@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for curve C at point P.
(b) Set up and evaluate an integral expression with respect to y that gives the area of S.

(c) Curve C is a part of the curve x2 - y2 = 1. Show that x2 - y2 = 1 can be written as the polar equation <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>r</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>cos</mi> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mi>θ</mi> <mo>−</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>sin</mi> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mi>θ</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@495C@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.
(d) Use the polar equation given in part (c) to set up an integral expression with respect to the polar angle θ that represents the area of S.

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
